metadata.sermon_start_end: The Psalm appointed for Ascension Day is #47. Here are a few verses from it: Clap your hands, all you peoples; shout to God with a cry of joy. For the Lord most high is to be feared; he is the great king over all the earth. [...] As the ecstatic crowd cheered and danced, the planes flew over in formation and from their tails there streamed clouds of vapor in rainbow colors. “The kingdom of this world has become the kingdom of our Lord and of his Christ” (Revelation 11:15). Verily, verily, Jesus Christ is “Lord of the dance.” Amen.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails Dekker’s first thesis fundamentally. It does not actualize one specific Bible passage but functions as a thematic speech on 'Ascension' and 'South Africa'. It jumps between Psalm 47, Hebrews, Acts, Ecclesiastes, and Revelation. The 'starting point' is the New York Times report, not the unique content of a specific pericope.
quotes: The Psalm appointed for Ascension Day is #47. Here are a few verses from it...
And here is the latest report from South Africa...
The Epistle to the Hebrews explains it...
In fact, in the reading for Ascension Day from the book of Acts...
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select one pericope (e.g., Psalm 47) and extract what is unique to that text which cannot be found elsewhere, rather than using it as a proof-text for political events.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is no formal exposition of the original context. The preacher does not address the Hebrew/Greek nuances or the historical context of the biblical books. The texts are treated as timeless slogans to be applied directly to 1994.
quotes: The meaning of Ascension Day is not that Jesus went up into the clouds...
The human heart is, as we read in Ecclesiastes, 'full of evil...'
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate scholarly exegesis of the chosen passage. For Psalm 47, explain its role in Israel's liturgy and its specific view of God's kingship before jumping to modern parallels.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: This is the sermon's strongest point, though it borders on 'general truth'. The application to the end of Apartheid is highly concrete. However, Dekker warns that application must stem from the text; here, the text is applied to the news, rather than the news being read through the specific lens of a text's unique contribution.
quotes: May God grant that we too will resist them in the streets and subways and workplaces of New York...
I spoke recently to a Christian woman who has struggled long and hard against her own personal demons...
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ensure the application is not just a 'happy thought' connecting news to liturgy, but a necessary consequence of the specific biblical exposition.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: While the sermon is not 'boring' (which Dekker warns against), it lacks interwoveness because there is almost no 'exposition' to interweave. The 'present of revelation' is sought in political history rather than in the movement of the Word itself.
quotes: It is hard to resist the happy thought that God planned the whole thing for the feast of the Ascension...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Draw the hearer into the biblical text first, so they are 'expounded' by the text, rather than using the text as a decorative frame for a political commentary.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The categories of misery (Apartheid/Rwanda/personal demons) and redemption (Mandela's inauguration/Christ's reign) are present. The sermon avoids being 'too objective' by mentioning the individual heart, but the 'misery' is often external (political) rather than the radical misery before God.
quotes: The human heart is... full of evil, and madness is in men’s hearts.
There are no devils left in Hell; they are all in Rwanda.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'misery' aspect by showing how the text (not just the news) exposes the hearer's own condition before God.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The 'two ways' are present in the contrast between Rwanda and South Africa, and the 'personal demons'. However, the 'seriousness of being lost' is mitigated by a very optimistic 'miracle' narrative. The ultimate possibility of destruction is mentioned but not as a pressing theological reality for the hearer.
quotes: The struggle between good and evil is... something that is taking place in each individual heart as well.
white people will keep on discriminating against black people just as they do here...
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the 'ultimate possibilities of life design' more sharply. What does it mean to be 'lost' in the context of the specific Bible passage?

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is the 'telos', but He often appears as an 'analogy' to Nelson Mandela. The doctrine of the two natures is implicit but not the driving force. Grace is present, but it feels like a 'human miracle' rather than salvation coming strictly from 'outside himself'.
quotes: Jesus is not only Lord of the rulers... he is Lord of each Christian.
In faith and hope the reality of his victory is already present, in the small and seemingly insignificant triumphs of the human spirit...
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Clarify that Christ's reign is not merely an 'analogy' to political shifts, but the ontological ground that makes such shifts possible.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 14 minutes (1450 words), the sermon falls short of Dekker’s 20-minute minimum. It lacks the 'breadth' required for theological 'depth'. It moves too quickly between anecdotes.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Increase the length by deepening the exegetical and dogmatic reflection. Spend more time on the 'why' of the text rather than the 'what' of the news.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon functions more as a topical address on political providence than a sermon in the Dekkerian sense. It lacks a specific biblical anchor, moving rapidly between various texts to support a narrative about South Africa. While it is concrete and avoids generalities, it substitutes biblical exegesis with journalistic commentary. The duration is insufficient for the depth Dekker demands.
strengths: Concrete application to contemporary events (South Africa 1994).
Avoids 'comical' or purely 'objective' views of the Ascension by insisting on Christ's current reign.
Maintains a psychological awareness of the 'individual heart' alongside the collective.
weaknesses: Lack of a single, specific Bible passage as the starting point.
Total absence of original-language exegesis or historical-critical context.
Duration is significantly below the 20-minute threshold.
Theological 'analogy' often places the human event (Mandela) in the foreground and the divine event (Ascension) in the background.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: According to Dekker’s criteria, this is not a sermon but a 'speech about the gospel' or 'the power of God' in history. It fails the formal definition of 'exposition and application of a specific Bible passage.' It is a poignant occasional address, but homiletically deficient.
